question: Let $A=\{a,b,c\}$, then the number of equivalence relations on A containing (b, c) is
explanation: Must contain (b,c). By symmetry, must contain (c,b).
Case 2: Add (a,b). Must add (b,a). By transitivity with (b,c), must add (a,c) and (c,a).
Any intermediate relation fails transitivity. So there are exactly 2 relations.
